title: Piadina (Italian Flatbread Sandwich)

Directions
For the Dough:
Adjust oven rack to middle position and preheat oven to 250℉ (120℃). In a medium bowl, thoroughly whisk together flour, salt, and baking soda. Use your finger to pinch the lard into the flour mixture until lard is broken into pea-sized or smaller pieces and coated with flour. Add milk and stir until a shaggy dough forms. Transfer dough to a clean work surface and knead until smooth, 3 to 5 minutes. Shape into a ball, cover dough loosely with plastic wrap and let rest for 20 minutes.
Serious Eats / Kevin White
Divide dough into 4 equal pieces and shape each into a ball. Cover dough balls loosely with plastic wrap and let rest for 20 minutes.
Serious Eats / Kevin White
On a lightly floured work surface, pat 1 dough ball into a 5-inch disk (keep remaining dough balls covered). Using a rolling pin, roll disk into a 10-inch circle, flouring counter and rolling pin as needed to prevent sticking (dough rounds should be ¼ inch thick—about the thickness of a piece of cardstock). Use a fork to lightly prick the dough rounds all over on just 1 side, making sure to prick all the way through to the other side (about 8 times); set aside and cover. Repeat with remaining dough balls.
Serious Eats / Kevin White
Preheat an empty 12-inch stainless-steel or cast iron skillet over medium-high heat until very hot (a drop of water dripped onto the surface should sizzle immediately), 2 to 4 minutes. Using a pastry brush, coat the hot skillet lightly with oil. Place 1 dough round into skillet and cook until the bottom side is spotty brown and bubbles form across the dough’s top surface, about 30 seconds. Using a spatula, flip dough and continue to cook until dough puffs and the second side is spotty brown, about 30 seconds. Use a spatula to transfer piadina to a rimmed baking sheet and hold warm in the oven while cooking the remaining piadine. Repeat with the remaining 3 dough rounds.
Serious Eats / Kevin White
For the Filling:
In a large bowl, toss arugula with olive oil and balsamic vinegar and season with salt and pepper to taste; set aside.
Serious Eats / Kevin White
If using stracchino or stracciatella,
working with 1 piadina at a time, spoon tablespoon sized dollops over top of piadina and spread over the surface, leaving a ½-inch border all the way around the perimeter.
If using burrata,
work over a bowl and use fingers to gently tear cheese into bite size pieces.Working with 1 piadina at a time
scatter 1/4 of the torn buratta cheese evenly over half of the piadina surface, leaving a 1/2-inch border around perimeter.
Serious Eats / Kevin White
Scatter 1 cup dressed arugula evenly over the cheese. Fold piadina in half (over the greens) and press gently to secure shut. Repeat steps 6 and 7 with the remaining 3 piadine. Slice in half and serve.
Serious Eats / Kevin White
Special Equipment
Rolling pin, 12-inch stainless-steel skillet, pastry brush, rimmed baking sheet
Make-Ahead and Storage
Once cooled, the cooked flatbread can be wrapped tightly with plastic wrap and stored at room temperature for up to 1 day. Reheat briefly in a skillet to warm through before building the sandwich.
